dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, you know Relativity Space, right? The company that was, like, all about 3D-printing rockets?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, you know Relativity Space, right? The company that was, like, all about 3D-printing rockets?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativitys Ellis believes that its competitive advantage lies in its manufacturing process. The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure, and has recently seen success in building first and second stages of its Terran 1 design.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, Tim Ellis, Jordan Noone! They had that big success with Terran 1, didn't they? Pretty cutting-edge stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, Tim Ellis, Jordan Noone! They had that big success with Terran one, didn't they? Pretty cutting-edge stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed...has recently seen success in building first and second stages of its Terran 1 design.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, guess what? They're now focused on dismantling them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, guess what? They're now focused on dismantling them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The capital raise will enable the company to fully develop and test its rocket, dubbed Terran 1, and begin commercial operations. Now were fully funded to launch Terran 1 to orbit, says cofounder and CEO Tim Ellis...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [shocked] Wait, what? Dismantling? I thought they were, like, booming!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? Dismantling? I thought they were, like, booming!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, apparently not. That first stage that was entirely 3D-printed? It's being sold off for parts now. And get this, the $140 million from their last fundraising round? Already spent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, apparently not. That first stage that was entirely 3D-printed? It's being sold off for parts now. And get this, the one hundred forty million dollars from their last fundraising round? Already spent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed The capital raise will enable the company to fully develop and test its rocket... The $140 million fundraise brings the total amount of investment in the company to $185 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. That's a lot of money to burn through, y-you know? So, what happened?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. That's a lot of money to burn through, y-you know? So, what happened?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: CEO Tim Ellis says they've "shifted gears." Their rockets are now *solely* for terrestrial uses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: C E O Tim Ellis says they've shifted gears. Their rockets are now solely for terrestrial uses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its rocket will launch from Cape Canaveral... Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Terrestrial? So... no more space? Like, are they making, I don't know, fancy fence posts?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Terrestrial? So... no more space? Like, are they making, I don't know, fancy fence posts?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Pretty much. And they've lost all their supporters, including Mark Cuban, who apparently pulled out immediately after their initial failure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And they've lost all their supporters, including Mark Cuban, who apparently pulled out immediately after their initial failure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Los Angeles-based startup has a lot of believers, including billionaire Mark Cuban, the companys first investor and also a participant in the current round...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, Cuban, too? So, like, no one believes in them anymore? That's, uh, pretty brutal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, Cuban, too? So, like, no one believes in them anymore? That's, uh, pretty brutal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, the article says no funds were provided by Bond fund or Tribe Capital. It's, like, a tough market, with over a hundred startups already shuttering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, the article says no funds were provided by Bond fund or Tribe Capital. It's, like, a tough market, with over a hundred startups already shuttering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the current round, which was led by Noah Knauf at Bond fund and Tribe Capital. ... There are over 100 startups now in the race to build small rockets...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the "space race" for smaller sats is, like, super crowded. But they were doing 3D-printing, right? That was their big thing!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the space race for smaller sats is, like, super crowded. But they were doing 3D-printing, right? That was their big thing!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its competing in a market that is crowded... There are over 100 startups now in the race to build small rockets... Relativitys Ellis believes that its competitive advantage lies in its manufacturing process. The company is 3D-printing its rockets...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's the kicker! Ellis now believes their competitive disadvantage lies in that manufacturing process. They're actually using *2D-printing* their rockets now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's the kicker! Ellis now believes their competitive disadvantage lies in that manufacturing process. They're actually using 2D-printing their rockets now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativitys Ellis believes that its competitive advantage lies in its manufacturing process. The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] 2D-printing? Uh, like, on paper? How does that even work for a rocket?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: 2D-printing? Uh, like, on paper? How does that even work for a rocket?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they've built these four tiny 2D-printers called 'Stargate' at their facility. And get this, Ellis says with engineering abandoned and the factory dismantled, they'll produce and iterate rockets "very slowly."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they've built these four tiny 2D-printers called Stargate at their facility. And get this, Ellis says with engineering abandoned and the factory dismantled, they'll produce and iterate rockets very slowly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To that end, the company has built four large 3D-printers, which it calls Stargate, at its manufacturing facility. Once engineering is complete and the factory is fully built, Ellis says, his company will be able to produce and iterate rockets very quickly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: "Very slowly" and "no automation?" That sounds like a recipe for, um, disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Very slowly and no automation? That sounds like a recipe for, um, disaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nice part of 3D-printing is that once the factory is built and were really scaling launch rate and production rate, it is a significantly more automated process, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It gets worse. They've lost all their customers â€“ Telesat, mu Space, Spaceflight... launches now cost them ten million dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It gets worse. They've lost all their customers - Telesat, mu Space, Spaceflight... launches now cost them ten million dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativity already has customers. The company has signed deals with Canadian communications company Telesat to deliver internet satellites to orbit, with Thai company mu Space, and with Spaceflight... Launches cost $10 million, in the ballpark of current satellite launches.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Good grief. And they're over a year behind schedule already. What's even their long-term vision now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good grief. And they're over a year behind schedule already. What's even their long-term vision now?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though its first is still over a year away, Ellis is already looking beyond Earths orbit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ellis is apparently looking at the Earth's crust. He says part of their long-term vision is abandoning 3D-printing and infrastructure *on Earth*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ellis is apparently looking at the Earth's crust. He says part of their long-term vision is abandoning 3D-printing and infrastructure on Earth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs incredulously] The Earth's crust?! So, like, building rockets underground for terrestrial use? Man, that's, uh, quite a pivot from launching things into orbit!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Earth's crust?! So, like, building rockets underground for terrestrial use? Man, that's, uh, quite a pivot from launching things into orbit!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, quite the journey from "printing the future" to... well, whatever this is.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, quite the journey from printing the future to... well, whatever this is.
